intro: Leucophyllum ultramonticola, commonly known as the Texas mountain laurel, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Lythraceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, clustered white or pinkish flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 10 feet, and is well adapted to arid and rocky environments. Its leaves are opposite, lance-shaped, and have a leathery texture, while its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer. The Texas mountain laurel is also known for its ability to thrive in poor soils and its resistance to drought conditions.
